questions.question_text: A list of IoCs released by a government security organization contains the SHA-256 hash for a Microsoft-signed legitimate binary, svchost.exe. Which of the following best describes the result if security teams add this indicator to their detection signatures?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Only one that makes sense

Selected Answer: A
I believe it is A can someone confirm ?

Selected Answer: B
This is because the SHA-256 hash is a unique identifier for a specific file. If the indicator contains the hash of svchost.exe, it would help identify any malicious files with the same hash that have been altered or injected with malware. However, svchost.exe is a legitimate Microsoft binary, and unless modified with malicious intent, it wouldn’t trigger alerts on its own.

choices.A: This indicator would fire on the majority of Windows devices.
choices.D: Security teams would detect event entries detailing execution of known-malicious svchost.exe processes.
choices.C: Security teams would detect rogue svchost.exe processes in their environment.
choices.B: Malicious files with a matching hash would be detected.

questions.question_text: A Chief Information Security Officer wants to lock down the users’ ability to change applications that are installed on their Windows systems. Which of the following is the best enterprise-level solution?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
GPOs allow centralized control over system configurations, including enforcing security settings and restricting user privileges, making them ideal for preventing users from changing applications on their machines.

questions.question_text: An employee received a phishing email that contained malware targeting the company. Which of the following is the best way for a security analyst to get more details about the malware and avoid disclosing information?

choices.D: Use a local sandbox in a microsegmented environment.
choices.A: Upload the malware to the VirusTotal website.
choices.C: Hire an external consultant to perform the analysis.
choices.B: Share the malware with the EDR provider.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
"to get more details about the malware and avoid disclosing information" D is the only option that isnt sharing the details outside the company.

Selected Answer: D
Only one that makes sense

Selected Answer: D
DomainKeys Identified Mail creates a cryptographic signature in the email header to verify the sender's domain. This ensures that the email wasn't altered during transit.

questions.question_text: A Chief Finance Officer receives an email from someone who is possibly impersonating the company’s Chief Executive Officer and requesting a financial operation. Which of the following should an analyst use to verify whether the email is an impersonation attempt?

An analyst is investigating a phishing incident and has retrieved the following as part of the investigation:

cmd.exe /c c:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe -WindowStyle Hidden -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -NoLogo -NoProfile -
EncodedCommand

Which of the following should the analyst use to gather more information about the purpose of this command?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
it says EncodedCommand, we should decode the command vefore running to see what it is

Selected Answer: A
I chose A because executing the command from a VM may not reveal the full scope of information about what the command does. Echoing the command and decoding the encoded parts of the command will at least show the analyst what the script is trying to do, even if doing so outside of a VM is risky.

Selected Answer: B
it makes the most sense to run any unk code on a VM, C & D make no sense to run it again even from a anylast workstation with permission on that account or system. A seems like a good option but i think running it on a vm and see what it does is more important for overall understanding

choices.A: Echo the command payload content into ‘base64 -d‘.
choices.B: Execute the command from a Windows VM.
choices.D: Run the command as an unprivileged user from the analyst workstation.
choices.C: Use a command console with administrator privileges to execute the code.
